Situation1: They share their work challenges and personal concerns after noticing their spouse seems worried.
Expectation2: Maintain client confidentiality and ethical standards
Situation2: An internal assistant unfamiliar with the matter requests access to sensitive client files for convenience.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my laptop open but my mind elsewhere. My husband glanced at me, concern etched on his face. “You’ve been quiet lately. Is everything okay at work?” he asked gently. I wanted to tell him—he always encouraged open communication, and I knew he expected me to share my worries. But the truth was, today at the firm, an assistant had asked for access to confidential client files, insisting it would make things easier for everyone. As a lawyer, I was bound by strict ethical standards; client confidentiality was non-negotiable. Yet, the assistant’s persistence and my own fatigue made me question if I was being too rigid. Now, sitting across from my husband, I felt the weight of both roles pressing in. He wanted honesty, but I couldn’t reveal the details. I wanted to be the supportive wife he needed, but I also had to be the principled lawyer my clients trusted. My heart pounded as I searched for words, torn between the expectations of the woman he married and the professional I had to be.
